captions.text:
Captions by www.SubPLY.com
. . . . . . . . . . . . .
A new tourist destination in Auburn Hills, Michigan,
is showing visitors, the difficulties life held
for Americans in the past. Blockbuster video
aims to transport visitors to a time before the internet.
It's an historically authentic recreation of a video store,
a specialty shop where customers exchanged money for the short-term
use of videos in an archaic system called renting.
The tour is amazing, it's like stepping
into a time machine. It's hard to believe
that people lived this way. -A historical research team
spent 3 years making sure every last detail was accurate,
from the signs used, to promote the store's merchandise
to the costumes worn by the store's employees.
Historical performers who  make history come alive
for tour groups, twice an hour. -My character is based on
an actual Blockbuster employee named Jerome, who worked there
from May of 1999 to June 2000.
My main responsibilities are to man the cash register,
and to put the movies from the return slot,
back on to the shelves.
I am a Blockbuster customer named Cathy.  Two times a week,
I travel 6 miles to rent and return videos.
Oh look, we're in the  comedy section.
What's so poignant about this time,
is the uncertainty. When you get to the Blockbuster,
are they gonna have  your video?
Did someone else rent it? Is there gonna be a line?
Are the alarms gonna sound when you walk out the front door?
It was very difficult for the people that lived during this era.
Actors say, their job, is to create a historically
authentic experience. -Yes we have it,
but our only copy is currently checked out.
After the organized tour, visitors are allowed to
move around, the store, exploring  the so-called, living museum.
It's really amazing that people had to go through so much
just to get a movie. -Blockbuster joins
a growing number of historical tourism sites,
including Buffalo New York's recreation of
Virgin Records Music Store, and Iowa City's
Borders Bookstore Museum.

. . . . . . . . . . . .
Captions by www.SubPLY.com

title: Blockbuster Offers Glimpse Of Movie Renting Past

comments.author: Shaun Hamilton

comments.text:
I remember a time when I was a kid, I traveled with my mom to the video 
store to check out the latest movies on a Saturday night. Being excited to 
go, we jump in the car and head out downtown till I can see the shimmering 
light of the neon blue sign as we got closer.

Getting out of the car, walking up the sidewalk, reach out and open those 
glass doors to be greeted with a plastic aroma in the air. A semi quiet but 
relaxing atmosphere in a plethora of movies surrounding me. Walking in past 
the security detectors, I walked row by row and seeing a cutout of 'Honey, 
I shrunk the kids' next to the comedy section.

I would explore the Sci-fi section for the latest Godzilla movie I haven't 
seen yet (I was allowed to pick one movie for myself). Then after me and my 
mom picked our plastic boxes, we head to the check out stand, ring up, 
receipt out and ventured back home.

Later in life, I would go with a couple friends to check out a local 
Hollywood video on a Friday night. It was an awesome feeling renting a PS2 
game for the weekend after a long, hard week of school. Discovering new 
genres of entertainment like Anime (my first being Akira).

Today, I simply tune in on a few apps like Netflix, Amazon Prime, and 
Redbox if I feel the need to watch the newest release. I will dearly miss 
the feeling of walking through a library of films and their fantastic box 
art.

Heh, I never would of thought of judging a book by it's cover, but it 
helped me make my decisions even after reading the back side of the empty 
box. Now....I simply look at the ratings on a virtual screen without a 
second glance.

I'll truly miss those days. Goodbye, Blockbuster.﻿
comments.author: ProjectGibix

comments.text:
Sadly the last Blockbusters will close it doors on Monday. Considering this 
video was made nearly six years ago, its not too soon.﻿
comments.author: Matthew Beckly

comments.text:
Yet as terrible as it was...I will kind of miss the feeling I had as a kid 
seeing new movies or games on the shelves to rent. Running around looking 
at all the different options presented before me and enjoying most of my 
choices while I watched several different films just waiting for next week 
to grab other I had spotted on my previous trip that looked interesting. 
Now I sit here in this chair...immobile and clicking through an endless 
amount of options at any time just hoping the next movie wont suck as much 
as the one I just rented. No real sense of joy or anticipation most of the 
time...just an older cynical man with too much trashy media  to sort 
through at the cost of valuable time.﻿

knowing I just got my own copy at home. That was before torrent era. I also

a year, it was absolute hell and I've seen so many people being screwed 
over by faulty hardware, and other previous renters not giving a crap about 
how they abuse the movies for the next people because "they're only a 
dollar".. And what's worse is it's incredibly difficult to help them in any 
morally correct way without being fired. If you have a functioning internet 
connection, I have one word to say to you: uTorrent.
